comment.author: 14481705@N04
comment._content: This building is still around as well. It's the Old Parliament House for the Greek Parliament from 1875 and 1932. It currently houses the National Historical Museum.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: mosley.brian: Thanks for the information.  We will add it to the source data and reload the description.

comment.author: 64379474@N00
comment._content:
I'm not sure if this is acceptable but here is a photograph of this building taken (by me) in 2008.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/64379474@N00/2808151971/]

comment.author: 7364400@N04
comment._content: I am wondering which exact year this photo was taken? I think it must be taken in 1915 and why I assume this? Well then it was when the so called "National Schism" (1914-1917) took place and it was a dispute between the King and the Prime Minister. So, since the legitimate government was re-established in Thessaloniki (the second largest city in Greece), in the north. In Athens the then-Parliament was closed and possibly that is why there is no flag on its pole!

comment.author: 35234565@N04
comment._content: Thank you so much for this added insight into why the building looks so deserted, except for the person sitting on the stairs.  We can certainly make an adjustment to the date range for the image the next time we update the record. And thanks to you, Tilemahos for the addition of the recent photograph. It's always acceptable.

comment.author: 7364400@N04
comment._content:
New update: After studying very carefully that photo, I noticed that down bellow far on the right corner there is a mark left by a stamp. On that mark it says: "1915/12". Interpreting from that, I assume now evidently that this photo has either taken on December 1915 (which is more likely!) or it has been published on that same date. Nevertheless take into consideration that evident and update accordingly the record. 

Kind regards and respect for your contribution.

George A. Voudouris
